<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HOUSING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/zillow-stops-buying-houses-for-the-rest-of-the-year?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Even Zillow Got Sick of Surfing Zillow
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/zillow-stops-buying-houses-for-the-rest-of-the-year?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A house in a frozen block of ice " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/927c2d0f2655659e9deac0cc94a8464d1c8508cf-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The online real estate giant said it’ll <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-17/zillow-pauses-home-purchases-as-snags-hit-tech-powered-flipping?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stop flipping houses</a> for the remainder of 2021.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zillow flips houses?</strong> While it’s best known as the platform for browsing home listings in Bozeman you can't afford, Zillow has also bought and sold houses for the past three years in an automated process known as <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/16/realestate/ibuying-real-estate-what-it-is-and-where-it-is-happening.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">iBuying</a>. In iBuying, a seller will input information about their property online, then a company’s algorithm will sort through the data and spit out an offer in as little as 24 hours.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But it’s not a <em>fully </em>automated process, and that’s where Zillow is in a pickle. The company that’s doing the iBuying sends a representative to inspect the property and do a gut check on the offer. But Zillow says it doesn’t have enough of those people (given the historic labor shortage and whatnot) and therefore can’t add any new houses on top of its current backlog.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It’s a big deal—Zillow’s stock fell 9.4%, its biggest drop in months, in response to the news.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s because Zillow’s house-flipping unit, called Zillow Offers, is a big deal, accounting for <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/zillow-says-it-cant-buy-any-more-homes-this-year-11634574144?mod=lead_feature_below_a_pos1" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than 50%</a> of the company’s revenue last year. And it’s growing: Zillow bought 3,805 homes in Q2, more than it had in any other quarter by far.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Rivals see an opening</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Opendoor is grinning like a sprinter whose opponent just went down with a cramp. Following the Zillow news, the iBuying startup boasted it was “open for business.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Opendoor was already a busier house-flipper than Zillow, more than doubling Zillow’s home-buying total in Q2 with 8,494 purchases.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Another startup brimming with schadenfreude: </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/offerpads-hustle-is-worth-appreciating-11616670731?mod=article_inline" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Offerpad</a></span><span>, which recently went public and manages to squeeze more profits out of each home flip than Opendoor or Zillow.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Zillow’s flip-flop comes amid signs that the moonbound housing market might finally be <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-18/zillow-s-flipping-snag-spotlights-risk-in-cooling-housing-market?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">parachuting back to Earth</a>. The median home sale price increased 14% annually in September, its lowest growth rate since last December, per Redfin.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/the-sec-releases-highly-anticipated-report-on-gamestop-frenzy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The SEC Reflects on the GameStop Saga
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/the-sec-releases-highly-anticipated-report-on-gamestop-frenzy?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="GameStop under a magnifying glass" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/f3ddb3ca48886ba8d4bf9366761b3f536e1d58eb-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sec-report-on-gamestop-saga-declines-to-rule-on-causes-of-trade-restrictions-11634589248?mod=home-page" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">long-awaited report</a> on the meme stock trading frenzy this winter, the SEC concluded that the entire episode showed that US financial markets generally work as they’re supposed to.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quick recap: </strong>Shares in the struggling video game retailer GameStop <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sec-report-on-gamestop-saga-declines-to-rule-on-causes-of-trade-restrictions-11634589248?mod=home-page" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">erupted 2,700%</a> in value from January 8 to January 28, a rally that appeared to begin as a coordinated effort by individual investors to fleece hedge funds who were shorting the stock.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So what did the SEC find?</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">That “short squeeze” wasn’t a big factor in the rally. </strong></span><span>The SEC said that investors trying to profit from short-sellers’ collapse was a “small fraction of overall buy volume,” and they attributed the majority of GameStop’s skyrocketing share price to “positive sentiment.”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">No proof Robinhood did anything shady. </strong></span><span>Robinhood halted trading for certain meme stocks at the height of the frenzy, citing liquidity issues. While conspiracies swirled that it did so for nefarious reasons, the SEC couldn’t find any evidence to support that rumor.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the SEC said it’ll use the GameStop saga as an “opportunity to reflect” on the ways financial markets function, but other than that—keep calm and trade on, folks.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/amazon-s-150k-seasonal-hiring-spree-could-happen-in-the-midst-of-a-criminal-investigation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Amazon Goes on Offense and Defense
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Amazon heard the Great Resignation news and said, “more for us.” It’s <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/amazon-offers-bonuses-in-aim-to-hire-1500000-seasonal-workers-164132584.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">planning to hire</a> 150,000 seasonal workers for this year’s holiday season. To attract notoriously picky workers in 2021, it’s dangling signing bonuses of up to $3,000 and recently bumped average starting pay to $18/hr.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>For comparison, the “oh frick, I need a picture frame by TOMORROW” retailer hired 100k seasonal staff last year to keep up with the pandemic-induced online shopping boom.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But that’s not all Andy Jassy is prepping for. </strong>Five members of the House Judiciary Committee <a href="https://apnews.com/article/technology-business-amazoncom-inc-apple-inc-criminal-investigations-9d0c8f92f58753aa6df3bb75787ad17f?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sent</a> the Amazon CEO a letter Sunday saying the company has one more chance to “correct the record” on previous testimonies or a criminal investigation may be on the horizon.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>After articles from </span><span><a href="https://themarkup.org/amazons-advantage/2021/10/14/amazon-puts-its-own-brands-first-above-better-rated-products?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Markup</a></span><span> and </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/amazon-india-rigging?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Reuters</a></span><span> last week accused the company of using data from third-party sellers to inform the creation of its own products, the committee said that completely contradicts what Amazon execs, including former CEO Jeff Bezos, told Congress in the past. </span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Amazon is no stranger to government threats, but a criminal investigation could dampen its big holiday plans.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

</h3>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/key-performance-indicators-october-19?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Sopranos characters golfing" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1889b317a167f755e31b1280f0f96b87df7d5609-1200x675.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>HBO</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>New Jersey became the <a href="https://apnews.com/article/sports-business-atlantic-city-sports-betting-gambling-industry-7be570d48a614d3b17ab7e8bebafbc86?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first state</a> to record more than $1 billion worth of sports bets in a single month in September. After winning bets and other expenses were paid out, casinos and racetracks took home $82 million.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“If you really want an offensive slogan on your car, then you can use a bumper sticker.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Maine Secretary of State Shenna Bellows <a href="https://apnews.com/article/oddities-business-maine-eb34f0bb19717f4bde2cabfe4c100c7c?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">defended</a> the state’s new law that bans profanities on license plates. Today we’re summoning the energy of the Maine driver whose license plate just reads, “F---—YoU,” but actually spelled out.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Can MasterClass teach you everything? (<a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2021/10/25/can-masterclass-teach-you-everything?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The New Yorker</a>)</p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/apple-unveils-new-macbook-pros-airpods-and-faster-chips?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Apple Unveils New Products, Still Loves Saying "Liquid Retina"
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/18/apple-unveils-new-macbook-pros-airpods-and-faster-chips?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A sonic wave coming out of a third generation AirPod" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1e129b59cd9052bfaff10a185d46a1074bc455ab-1908x1076.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Apple</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Apple hosted its second hardware event of the fall yesterday and still no new iPod Touch. Instead, the company announced third-generation AirPods, improved M1 chips, and powerful new MacBook Pros.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Starting with the AirPods: </strong>They got a <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/18/22671344/apple-new-airpods-3-spacial-audio-specs-price-release-date-features?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new design</a> featuring shorter stems. AirPods 3 (unofficial name) will retail for $179, have an improved listening time of six hours, and support spatial audio—essentially mobile surround sound. They’ll also be water and sweat resistant. You can find them in stores on October 26, and lost in your couch cushions or maybe somewhere in the car sometime after that.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Pros: </strong>Apple unveiled two new MacBook Pros, a 14-inch starting at $1,999, and a 16-inch starting at $2,499. Missing from both: the Touch Bar. Included in both: Apple’s new chips, either the M1 Pro or the M1 Max—four-wheel drive versions of the M1 chip Apple debuted last fall as part of its mission to rid itself of its <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-07/apple-preps-next-mac-chips-with-aim-to-outclass-highest-end-pcs?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Intel dependency</a>. Also returning: an HDMI port and an SD card slot.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Honorable mentions:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>New colors of the HomePod Mini</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A $4.99 Apple Music plan</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eiBuying\u003c/a\u003e. In iBuying, a seller will input information about their property online, then a company’s algorithm will sort through the data and spit out an offer in as little as 24 hours.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut it’s not a \u003cem\u003efully \u003c/em\u003eautomated process, and that’s where Zillow is in a pickle. The company that’s doing the iBuying sends a representative to inspect the property and do a gut check on the offer. But Zillow says it doesn’t have enough of those people (given the historic labor shortage and whatnot) and therefore can’t add any new houses on top of its current backlog.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt’s a big deal—Zillow’s stock fell 9.4%, its biggest drop in months, in response to the news.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s because Zillow’s house-flipping unit, called Zillow Offers, is a big deal, accounting for \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/zillow-says-it-cant-buy-any-more-homes-this-year-11634574144?mod=lead_feature_below_a_pos1\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than 50%\u003c/a\u003e of the company’s revenue last year. And it’s growing: Zillow bought 3,805 homes in Q2, more than it had in any other quarter by far.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eRivals see an opening\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOpendoor is grinning like a sprinter whose opponent just went down with a cramp. Following the Zillow news, the iBuying startup boasted it was “open for business.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOpendoor was already a busier house-flipper than Zillow, more than doubling Zillow’s home-buying total in Q2 with 8,494 purchases.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnother startup brimming with schadenfreude: \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/offerpads-hustle-is-worth-appreciating-11616670731?mod=article_inline\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eOfferpad\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, which recently went public and manages to squeeze more profits out of each home flip than Opendoor or Zillow.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eZillow’s flip-flop comes amid signs that the moonbound housing market might finally be \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-18/zillow-s-flipping-snag-spotlights-risk-in-cooling-housing-market?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eparachuting back to Earth\u003c/a\u003e. The median home sale price increased 14% annually in September, its lowest growth rate since last December, per Redfin.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sec-report-on-gamestop-saga-declines-to-rule-on-causes-of-trade-restrictions-11634589248?mod=home-page\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elong-awaited report\u003c/a\u003e on the meme stock trading frenzy this winter, the SEC concluded that the entire episode showed that US financial markets generally work as they’re supposed to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eQuick recap: \u003c/strong\u003eShares in the struggling video game retailer GameStop \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/sec-report-on-gamestop-saga-declines-to-rule-on-causes-of-trade-restrictions-11634589248?mod=home-page\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eerupted 2,700%\u003c/a\u003e in value from January 8 to January 28, a rally that appeared to begin as a coordinated effort by individual investors to fleece hedge funds who were shorting the stock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo what did the SEC find?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThat “short squeeze” wasn’t a big factor in the rally. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe SEC said that investors trying to profit from short-sellers’ collapse was a “small fraction of overall buy volume,” and they attributed the majority of GameStop’s skyrocketing share price to “positive sentiment.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNo proof Robinhood did anything shady. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRobinhood halted trading for certain meme stocks at the height of the frenzy, citing liquidity issues. While conspiracies swirled that it did so for nefarious reasons, the SEC couldn’t find any evidence to support that rumor.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe SEC said it’ll use the GameStop saga as an “opportunity to reflect” on the ways financial markets function, but other than that—keep calm and trade on, folks.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eApple hosted its second hardware event of the fall yesterday and still no new iPod Touch. Instead, the company announced third-generation AirPods, improved M1 chips, and powerful new MacBook Pros.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStarting with the AirPods: \u003c/strong\u003eThey got a \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/18/22671344/apple-new-airpods-3-spacial-audio-specs-price-release-date-features?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew design\u003c/a\u003e featuring shorter stems. AirPods 3 (unofficial name) will retail for $179, have an improved listening time of six hours, and support spatial audio—essentially mobile surround sound. They’ll also be water and sweat resistant. You can find them in stores on October 26, and lost in your couch cushions or maybe somewhere in the car sometime after that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe Pros: \u003c/strong\u003eApple unveiled two new MacBook Pros, a 14-inch starting at $1,999, and a 16-inch starting at $2,499. Missing from both: the Touch Bar. Included in both: Apple’s new chips, either the M1 Pro or the M1 Max—four-wheel drive versions of the M1 chip Apple debuted last fall as part of its mission to rid itself of its \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-07/apple-preps-next-mac-chips-with-aim-to-outclass-highest-end-pcs?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eIntel dependency\u003c/a\u003e.
